div.p: Highlighted text potential contravention of TO policy
GRG 19/391, State Records of South Australia, Adelaide.

To proof.
[1894]
editorial addition — date of specimens at MEL. The sequence 1-200 may have been done by M at the same time even though the lists are on seventeen sheets of paper. The end of each sheet is marked with a line in the text given here.

1,Hibiscus pentaphyllus F.vM
Specimen of Hibiscus pentaphyllus (MEL 1504800) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 1.

39,Pollichia latisepalea, FvM
Interlined annotation: '38 Same as No 31 evidently but think mistake as these dont dry well'.

Kindly describe the exact color of the flowers, whether throughout blue or white or yellow at the bottom. Do the Dromedaries like this as much as the allied P. Zeila mica. Could some ripe seeds be obtained
MS annotation: 'Light Blue with green centre where pistils are. Dont know if camels fond of it.'
All your saltbushes there need special attention)

(No good flowers on the specimen) Is the fruit bitter?
MS annotation: '(Yes)'.

43,Hibiscus without fruit
without fruit deleted and annotated: 'sent'.

Kindly send ripe fruits of such like little herbs the seeds are much in demand at European University-Gardens, so as to rear these easy grown plantlets for demonstrations to the students from living state in pots
This was discovered by Waterhouse in Stuarts last expedition. As it is not yet in gardens, seeds would be particularly acceptable.

Fruit required also. This is a difficult genus to determine species in
MS annotation: 'sent'.

53,Evolvulus linifolius, L
Specimen of Evolvulus linifolius (MEL 561536) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 53.
Either N. gracilis Bentham or N. monosperma, F.v.M. The ripe fruit will show this

Seeds much desired. Are the flowers fragrant?
MS annotation: '(yes)'.
Ripe fruit also required as the spec. are much determined from characters of the seeds (ripe)

Does this sometimes ripen pods underground? Do you find little tubules on the roots?
MS annotation: '(never noticed)'.

Have you more than one species there. Are cattle and horses fond of it and Dromedaries? What do the Camels browse on in predilection.
MS annotation: 'Only one I know of. Middling fond. dont know.'

63,Hibiscus (Abelmoschus) What is the color of the fresh flowers. Fruits also wanted.
MS annotation: 'Creamy. old seeds sent'.

Seeds of any Drosera welcome.
MS annotation: 'sent'.

[6]6,
editorial addition — MS damaged. All square brackets in the following text have this meaning. Salsola Kiali, Linné
So far as can be judged without fruits being available

I should like to see more of this. It seems new for North-Australia
MS annotation: 'Will repeat. old seeds sent.'

Can you distinguish more than one spec. there by the color of the flowers and other characteristics?
MS annotation: 'Not noticed will see.'
Could you kindly secure fruit specimens of this, and send [me] some more flowers for dissect[ion]

What is the color of the flowers? In any answers, kindly quote the genus not the number
MS annotation: '(white)'.
In this large genus the spec. cannot be named with safety in the absence of fruit

Fruit wanting. Are the fresh flowers white?
MS annotation: 'yes'.
This elegant plant would make a nice pot plant in home conservatories. Could seeds be obtained
Berry also required and note on its fresh color
The genus contains several hundred species ; it wants the help of the ripe fruits to make them out
84,Can you oblige with seeds of any of your Eucalypts
You will likely find allied species there

87/165
165 is written below 87 by unknown. Acacia

Seeds of all your Acacias are acceptable
MS annotation: 'Sent'.

136,Acacia retivenia, FvM
Specimen of Acacia retivenia (MEL number) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 136.

152,Acacia stipuligera, FvM
Specimen of Acacia stipuligera (MEL number) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 152.
114,Melaleuca leucodendron L. the red fl. variety
Is this used by the natives as a medicine
Could good seeds be obtained easily?

15, Achyranthes excelsa
excelsa deleted by unknown.
What is the color of the fresh flowers? Have you more sp. there?
perhaps A. xylocarpa Cunn but the fruit is to young to make sure.

124Acacia coriacea, D.C.
Specimen of Acacia coriacea (MEL number) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 124.

103Acacia lysiphloia FvM
Specimen of Acacia lysiophloia (MEL number) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 103.

196,Acacia plectocarpa, Cunn
Specimen of Acacia plectocarpa (MEL number) collected by W. Holtze, Powell Creek, NT, 1894, no. 196.

Should you have noticed, dear Mr Holtze, that herds and flocks are fond
particularly of any herb or other plant, will you kindly name the species or send a specimen.
